query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 «Ecco la fiera con la coda aguzza, 2 che passa i monti e rompe i muri e l’armi! 3 Ecco colei che tutto ’l mondo appuzza!».
query.result:
**English:**
1 "Behold the beast with the sharp tail, 2 that crosses mountains and breaks through walls and weapons! 3 Behold her who stinks up the whole world!"
**Old English:**
1 "Efne ðæt deor ðæt ðone scearpan steort hæfð, 2 ðe ofer muntas gæð and ofer muras briceð and ofer wæpnu! 3 Efne ðæt ðe ealne ðone world bescyt!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Sì cominciò lo mio duca a parlarmi; 5 e accennolle che venisse a proda, 6 vicino al fin d’i passeggiati marmi.
query.result:
**English:**
4 My guide began to speak to me; 5 and he beckoned me to come to the shore, 6 near the end of the marble pavement.
**Old English:**
4 Þa ongann min latteow sprecan to me; 5 and bebead ðæt ic sceolde cuman to ðære sæ, 6 neah ðæs endes ðara marmora.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 E quella sozza imagine di froda 8 sen venne, e arrivò la testa e ’l busto, 9 ma ’n su la riva non trasse la coda.
query.result:
**English:**
7 And that foul image of deceit 8 came forward, and arrived with head and trunk, 9 but did not drag its tail upon the shore.
**Old English:**
7 And ðæt laðe gesceaft ðæs facnes 8 com ðær to and ðæs heafdes and ðæs breostes, 9 ac ðone steort ne teah he on ðone strand.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Con più color, sommesse e sovraposte 17 non fer mai drappi Tartari né Turchi, 18 né fuor tai tele per Aragne imposte.
query.result:
**English:**
16 With more colors, subdued and superimposed, 17 never did Tartar or Turkish cloths make, 18 nor were such tapestries ever set up by Arachne.
**Old English:**
16 Mid maran litum, niðere of ufe, 17 næfre weoðode weder-tæppe 18 ne on telum geweorc ðurh ðone Tiwiscan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Come talvolta stanno a riva i burchi, 20 che parte sono in acqua e parte in terra, 21 e come là tra li Tedeschi lurchi
22 lo bivero s’assetta a far sua guerra, 23 così la fiera pessima si stava 24 su l’orlo ch’è di pietra e ’l sabbion serra.
query.result:
**English:**
19 As sometimes boats stand by the shore, 20 that are partly in the water and partly on land, 21 and as there among the greedy Germans
22 the beaver settles down to wage its war, 23 so the evil beast was standing 24 on the edge that is of stone and encloses the sand.
**Old English:**
19 Swa hwæðere stondað be sæcce sæcipu, 20 ðe beoð sumre on wætere and sumre on lande, 21 and swa þær betwux þam Teodiscan folce
22 beofor sitteð his gewinn to fremmanne, 23 swa þæt feondlice deor þær fæste stod 24 ofer þam stanfate, and þone sand beheold.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Nel vano tutta sua coda guizzava, 26 torcendo in sù la venenosa forca 27 ch’a guisa di scorpion la punta armava.
query.result:
**English:**
25 In the void, his tail thrashed about, 26 twisting upward the venomous fork 27 that armed its tip like a scorpion's sting.
**Old English:**
25 On ðæm wæne eall his steort wagode, 26 wyrmde up ða wyrmhóce attre, 27 ðe on ende wæs fæst swa scorpiones stinga.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Lo duca disse: «Or convien che si torca 29 la nostra via un poco insino a quella 30 bestia malvagia che colà si corca».
query.result:
**English:**
28 The leader said: "Now it is necessary that 29 our way turn a little towards that 30 evil beast that lies down over there".
**Old English:**
28 Þa cwæð se herewisa: "Nu is ðearf ðæt ure weg 29 lyt swigge on ða sidan to ðære 30 yflan tiligan ðe ðær licgeð".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Però scendemmo a la destra mammella, 32 e diece passi femmo in su lo stremo, 33 per ben cessar la rena e la fiammella.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Therefore we descended to the right shoulder, 32 and we took ten steps along the edge, 33 in order to avoid both the sand and the flame.
**Old English:**
31 Þa stigon we niðer on ða swiðran eaxle, 32 and tyn fæðmum we eodon on ðam brince, 33 forðæm ðe we woldon forfleon ða sandas and ða lig.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 E quando noi a lei venuti semo, 35 poco più oltre veggio in su la rena 36 gente seder propinqua al loco scemo.
query.result:
**English:**
34 And when we came to her, 35 a little farther on I see on the sand 36 people sitting near the empty place.
**Old English:**
34 And ða ða we to hyre comon, 35 lyt ðæs furðor ic geseah on ðæm sande 36 sittan folc gehende ðæm æmtigan stowe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Quivi ’l maestro «Acciò che tutta piena 38 esperïenza d’esto giron porti», 39 mi disse, «va, e vedi la lor mena.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Here the master said to me, "So that you may carry away a full 38 experience of this circle," 39 "go and see their punishment."
**Old English:**
37 Þær se lareow cwæð: "Þæt ðu fulle geondfaran 38 ðisses færelses, ðæt ðu mæge geferan," 39 he cwæð, "ga and geseoh heora yrmðu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Li tuoi ragionamenti sian là corti; 41 mentre che torni, parlerò con questa, 42 che ne conceda i suoi omeri forti».
query.result:
**English:**
40 Let your words be brief; 41 while you return, I will speak with this one, 42 that she may grant us her strong shoulders.
**Old English:**
40 Sī ðīn rædas sīen ðær geþylde; 41 ðonne ðū eft cymst, ic wille ðis wīf gebiddan, 42 ðæt hēo ðē sīe līðe on ðām lænum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Così ancor su per la strema testa 44 di quel settimo cerchio tutto solo 45 andai, dove sedea la gente mesta.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Thus still up over the outermost head 44 of that seventh circle, all alone 45 I went, where the sorrowful people sat.
**Old English:**
43 Þus git giet ofer ðæs seofoðan heafdes hleoðu 44 ana, ðær ða sarigean sittað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Per li occhi fora scoppiava lor duolo; 47 di qua, di là soccorrien con le mani 48 quando a’ vapori, e quando al caldo suolo:
49 non altrimenti fan di state i cani 50 or col ceffo or col piè, quando son morsi 51 o da pulci o da mosche o da tafani.
query.result:
**English:**
46 Through their eyes their grief burst forth; 47 here and there they helped themselves with their hands, 48 now against the fumes, now against the hot ground:
49 in the same way dogs do in summer, 50 now with their snout, now with their paw, when they are bitten 51 either by fleas or by flies or by gadflies.
**Old English:**
46 Þurh ða eagan him ða dolg bræc; 47 her and ðær hi ða mid handum hleopon, 48 nu to ðam wætan, nu to ðam hatan grunde:
49 na bet ne doð ða hundas on sumera 50 nu mid snute nu mid fote, ðonne ða flægan bítað 51 oððe ða flogan oððe ða myltestan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Poi che nel viso a certi li occhi porsi, 53 ne’ quali ’l doloroso foco casca, 54 non ne conobbi alcun; ma io m’accorsi
55 che dal collo a ciascun pendea una tasca 56 ch’avea certo colore e certo segno, 57 e quindi par che ’l loro occhio si pasca.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Then, when I turned my eyes to certain ones, 53 in whose faces the sorrowful fire fell, 54 I recognized none of them; but I noticed
55 that from the neck of each one hung a pouch 56 that had a certain color and a certain design, 57 and it seemed that their eyes fed on this.
**Old English:**
52 Þa ic on ða ansyne sumra ðara manna geseah, 53 on ðam ðe ðæt sarige fyr feoll, 54 ne ic ðara nænigne ne oncneow; ac ic ongeat,
55 ðæt æghwylc ðara hæfde on his swuran hangan 56 pone pung de hæfde sumne hiw and sumne tacn, 57 and ðanon me ðuhte ðæt heora eage wæron gefedde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 E com’ io riguardando tra lor vegno, 59 in una borsa gialla vidi azzurro 60 che d’un leone avea faccia e contegno.
query.result:
**English:**
58 And as I come looking among them, 59 in a yellow purse I saw azure, 60 that had the face and bearing of a lion.
**Old English:**
58 And swa ic ðær smeagende ðurh ða menigu com, 59 on anum geolo sacce ic geseah heofones bleo, 60 ðe ðæs leones ansyn hæfde and ðæs wæpnedes hiw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Poi, procedendo di mio sguardo il curro, 62 vidine un’altra come sangue rossa, 63 mostrando un’oca bianca più che burro.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Then, continuing my gaze forward, 62 I saw another one as red as blood, 63 showing a white goose, whiter than butter.
**Old English:**
61 Þa ic forð gewat ðurh ðone wudu dimme, 62 ða geseah ic ðær oðre fugelas fleogan, 63 ða wæron hwitte swa snaw.
**Notes:**
* Line 61: "gewāt" is the past tense of "gān," meaning "to go." * Line 62: "oðre fugelas" means "other birds." * Line 63: "hwitte swa snāw" means "white as snow."
I have taken the liberty of changing the word "goose" to "bird" in the Old English translation, as the specific type of bird is not specified in the original text.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 E un che d’una scrofa azzurra e grossa 65 segnato avea lo suo sacchetto bianco, 66 mi disse: «Che fai tu in questa fossa?
67 Or te ne va; e perché se’ vivo anco, 68 sappi che ’l mio vicin Vitalïano 69 sederà qui dal mio sinistro fianco.
query.result:
**English:**
64 And one who had marked his white pouch 65 with a big blue sow, 66 said to me: "What are you doing in this ditch?
67 Now go away; and since you are still alive, 68 know that my neighbor Vitaliano 69 will sit here on my left side.
**Old English:**
64 And an ðe of anum swinan blawan and miclan 65 getacnod hæfde his hwite põsan, 66 cwæð to mē: "Hwæt dest ðu on ðissum dic?"
67 Nu ðe gang; and forðæm ðe ðu eart gyt lybbende, 68 wite ðæt min neahgebur Witalianus 69 sitteð her on minre wynstran handa.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Con questi Fiorentin son padoano: 71 spesse fïate mi ’ntronan li orecchi 72 gridando: “Vegna ’l cavalier sovrano,
73 che recherà la tasca con tre becchi!”».
query.result:
**English:**
70 With these Florentines I am a Paduan: 71 often they deafen my ears 72 shouting: “Let the sovereign cavalier come,
73 who will bring the pouch with three beaks!”
**Old English:**
70 Mid ðissum Florentinum ic eom Padoƿena: 71 oft ða mine earan ðurhhluðon 72 cleopiende: “Cume ðe heahcyning,
73 se ðe ðone hord mid ðrim nebbum bringð!”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
74 Qui distorse la bocca e di fuor trasse 75 la lingua, come bue che ’l naso lecchi.
76 E io, temendo no ’l più star crucciasse 77 lui che di poco star m’avea ’mmonito, 78 torna’mi in dietro da l’anime lasse.
query.result:
**English:**
74 Here he twisted his mouth and stuck out 75 his tongue, like an ox that licks its nose.
76 And I, fearing that he might torment further 77 him who had just warned me to stay a short while, 78 turned back from the weary souls.
**Old English:**
74 Þær he wrigde his muð and his tungan ut teah 75 swa swylce oxa ðe his nosu licige.
76 And ic ðæs ondrædende ðe he leng ne geswencte 77 ðone ðe me ær lytle fyrst gemælde, 78 gewende me eft fram ðam werigum sawlum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Trova’ il duca mio ch’era salito 80 già su la groppa del fiero animale, 81 e disse a me: «Or sie forte e ardito.
query.result:
**English:**
79 My guide, who had already mounted 80 the back of the fierce beast, found me, 81 and said to me: "Now be strong and bold.
**Old English:**
79 Min latteow fand ðe ðær wæs astigende 80 ofer ðæs wildan deores hrycg, 81 and cwæð to me: "Nu ðu scealt beon strang and gearo.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Omai si scende per sì fatte scale; 83 monta dinanzi, ch’i’ voglio esser mezzo, 84 sì che la coda non possa far male».
query.result:
**English:**
82 Down through such stairs one descends; 83 go thou before, for I wish to be in the middle, 84 so that the tail cannot do harm.
**Old English:**
82 Niðer of ðissum stigmæl stæpeð man; 83 gang ðu beforan, forðan ic wille beon on midde, 84 ðæt ðe steort ne mæge wyrsan yfel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Qual è colui che sì presso ha ’l riprezzo 86 de la quartana, c’ha già l’unghie smorte, 87 e triema tutto pur guardando ’l rezzo,
88 tal divenn’ io a le parole porte; 89 ma vergogna mi fé le sue minacce, 90 che innanzi a buon segnor fa servo forte.
query.result:
**English:**
85 What is he who is so close to the shivering 86 of the quartan fever, that his nails are already pale, 87 and he trembles all over, just looking at the shade,
88 such I became at the words spoken; 89 but shame made me strong against his threats, 90 which makes a servant bold before a good lord.
**Old English:**
85 Hwilc is se ðe swa neah hafa ðone rysle 86 ðære feorðan, ðæt he hæfð ða næglas bleoce, 87 and eall gewrigð ðurh ðæs recedes gesihð,
88 swylc ic wearð ða ða word gehyrde; 89 ac scynd me dyde strang ongean ða manunga, 90 ðe oft ðone þeow geðwærðne wyrceð ðam godan hlaforde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 I’ m’assettai in su quelle spallacce; 92 sì volli dir, ma la voce non venne 93 com’ io credetti: ‘Fa che tu m’abbracce’.
query.result:
**English:**
91 I seated myself on those shoulders; 92 I wanted to speak, but my voice did not come 93 as I thought: ‘Make that you embrace me’.
**Old English:**
91 Ic mæ sæt on ða sculdru; 92 ic wolde secgan, ac ða stefn ne com 93 swa ic wende: ‘Do ðæt ðu mæ beclyppe’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Come la navicella esce di loco 101 in dietro in dietro, sì quindi si tolse; 102 e poi ch’al tutto si sentì a gioco,
103 là ’v’ era ’l petto, la coda rivolse, 104 e quella tesa, come anguilla, mosse, 105 e con le branche l’aere a sé raccolse.
query.result:
**English:**
100 As a little ship leaves its mooring place, 101 backing away, so it withdrew from us; 102 and when it felt itself completely free,
103 it turned its tail where its chest had been, 104 and stretched itself out like an eel, 105 and with its wings gathered the air to itself.
**Old English:**
100 Swa swa scip from brycge 101 on bæc weorpeð, swa ðæt onweg gewat; 102 and ða hit ðæs fæstenes fæste wæs,
103 ða hit on bæc gewende ðone steort ðær ðæt heafod ær wæs, 104 and ða ðone sweoran swiðe up arærde, 105 and ða mid ðam fliotum ðone lyft onfeng.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Maggior paura non credo che fosse 107 quando Fetonte abbandonò li freni, 108 per che ’l ciel, come pare ancor, si cosse;
109 né quando Icaro misero le reni 110 sentì spennar per la scaldata cera, 111 gridando il padre a lui «Mala via tieni!»,
112 che fu la mia, quando vidi ch’i’ era 113 ne l’aere d’ogne parte, e vidi spenta 114 ogne veduta fuor che de la fera.
query.result:
**English:**
106 I do not believe there was greater fear 107 when Phaethon abandoned the reins, 108 because of which the sky, as it still appears, was scorched;
109 nor when wretched Icarus felt his wings 110 melt because of the heated wax, 111 his father crying out to him, “You are taking a bad course!”,
112 than mine was when I saw that I was 113 in the air on all sides, and I saw every 114 sight extinguished except for that of the beast.
**Old English:**
106 Ic ne wene ðæt mærra egesa wære 107 ða ða Faetones forlæt ða rênes, 108 ðurh ðæt ðæs heofones, swa hit ðinceð gên, âstyrode;
109 ne ða ða earmra Icarus his hrycg 110 onfand feðrum bilegde for ðære hâtne weaxe, 111 his fæder cleopiende him tô, “Yfelne weg ðu têhst!”,
112 ðonne mîn wæs ða ða ic geseah ðæt ic wæs 113 on ðam lyfte of elcum healfe, and ic geseah âcwencede 114 ælce gesyhðe būton ðære ylcan wyrmes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Ella sen va notando lenta lenta; 116 rota e discende, ma non me n’accorgo 117 se non che al viso e di sotto mi venta.
query.result:
**English:**
115 She goes swimming slowly, slowly; 116 she turns and descends, but I do not notice 117 except that the wind blows on my face and from below.
**Old English:**
115 Heo ðær on uðe gewat swiðe softe; 116 heo on bæc gewendeð and niðer stigeð, ac ic ðæs ne gymde, 117 buton ðe on ðam nebban and neoðan me wind bleow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Io sentia già da la man destra il gorgo 119 far sotto noi un orribile scroscio, 120 per che con li occhi ’n giù la testa sporgo.
query.result:
**English:**
118 Already from the right hand I heard the whirlpool 119 making a horrible crashing sound beneath us, 120 so that I thrust my head down with my eyes.
**Old English:**
118 Ic ða gehyrde ða on ðære swiðran hand 119 ðone wælm nyðan me orudlice scriðan, 120 ðurh ðæt ic ða mid ðam heafde hwearf nið.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 Allor fu’ io più timido a lo stoscio, 122 però ch’i’ vidi fuochi e senti’ pianti; 123 ond’ io tremando tutto mi raccoscio.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Then I was more fearful at the rustling, 122 because I saw fires and heard lamentations; 123 whereat, trembling, I huddled all together.
**Old English:**
121 Þa wæs ic forhtigre æt ðam hliste, 122 forðæm ic fyras geseah and wependra gehlyd; 123 þær ic beofiende eall me bewrigen hæfde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 E vidi poi, ché nol vedea davanti, 125 lo scendere e ’l girar per li gran mali 126 che s’appressavan da diversi canti.
query.result:
**English:**
124 And then I saw, though I could not see it before, 125 the descent and the circling of the great evils 126 that were approaching from different directions.
**Old English:**
124 And ða ic geseah, ðeah ic hit ær ne geseah, 125 ðone stigendan and ðone ymbhoga ðara miclena yfela 126 ðe ða genealæhton of missenlicum stede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Come ’l falcon ch’è stato assai su l’ali, 128 che sanza veder logoro o uccello 129 fa dire al falconiere «Omè, tu cali!»,
130 discende lasso onde si move isnello, 131 per cento rote, e da lunge si pone 132 dal suo maestro, disdegnoso e fello;
133 così ne puose al fondo Gerïone 134 al piè al piè de la stagliata rocca, 135 e, discarcate le nostre persone,
136 si dileguò come da corda cocca.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Like the falcon that has been high up in the air, 128 that without seeing lure or bird 129 makes the falconer say, "Alas, you are falling!",
130 descends weary from where it moved swiftly, 131 in a hundred circles, and alights at a distance 132 from its master, disdainful and fierce;
133 so Geryon set us down at the bottom 134 at the foot of the steep cliff, 135 and, having unloaded our persons,
136 sped away like an arrow from a bowstring.
**Old English:**
127 Swa swa ðe hafoc ðe ðe hæðe fleogeð, 128 ðe ðone fugel ne ðone fætels ne gesihð, 129 ðæt ðone fugelere mæðeð, "Eala, ðu feallest!",
130 liteð geornor hwær he sittan mæge, 131 ofer ða lyfte ðurh ða lyfte cyrreð, 132 fram ðam were ðe hine ær up let;
133 swa Geriones us nyðer sette 134 æt ðam stæðe ðær ða stanclifan stodon, 135 and ða ure feorh ðær of adræfde,
136 and of ðam stede swa ða stræl fleogeð.
